attributes.title: Effectiveness of Technology-Enhanced Dental Assessment of Undergraduate Preclinical Skills: A systematic review

q1.value: Effectiveness of technology-enhanced dental assessment of undergraduate preclinical skills: A systematic Review

q2.value: Shahd Hani Mustafa, Khaled Khalaf, Sausan Al Kawas, Mohamed Yahya El-Kishawi

q3.value: This is a systematic review which aims to investigate the effectiveness of technology-enhanced dental assessment tools on preclinical skills of undergraduate dental students in comparison to conventional preclinical assessment methods.

q4.value: If there is a difference between dental assessment methods, then technology-enhanced assessment methods will be more effective than the conventional assessment methods.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Our primary outcome is the effectiveness of technology-enhanced assessment methods compared to conventional assessment methods of preclinical skills in dental undergraduate students.

Our primary outcome is reviewing the effectiveness of technology-enhanced assessment methods in comparison to conventional assessment methods of preclinical skills in dental undergraduate students. Statistical heterogeneity among the trials will be assessed using χ² test where a p value of less than .1% will be considered as significant heterogeneity. The I² statistic test will be caried. The studies with more than 50% I² will be assessed as having significant heterogeneity. As we haven't started our data extraction, we are unable to judge which data synthesis we will use. That's why it is essential to measure the degree of heterogeneity among the trial results.

This is a systematic review. If the final studies to be included in the review reported the same outcome measure, and were not heterogenuous, and have a low risk of bias, then a formal meta-analysis will be carried out with the help of a formal qualified statistician.

attributes.title: Effects of schemata on variation (lexical decision)
attributes.withdrawal_justification: In this registration, numerical values about the prestudy were confused. The error has been corrected and a new version of the project has been registered.

attributes.title: Findings of a feasibility study of pre-operative pulmonary rehabilitation to reduce post-operative pulmonary complications in people with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease scheduled for major abdominal surgery

summary.value: Extended data for "Findings of a feasibility study of pre-operative pulmonary rehabilitation to reduce post-operative pulmonary complications in people with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease scheduled for major abdominal surgery"

registration_responses.summary: Extended data for "Findings of a feasibility study of pre-operative pulmonary rehabilitation to reduce post-operative pulmonary complications in people with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease scheduled for major abdominal surgery"

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

sample.value:
The sample size was estimated to be around Ni = 100 per cell, or N = 200 total, based on power analyses using G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007). These calculations are based on a 5% alpha-level, 85% statistical power, and effect sizes around d = .3 as reported by Harris, Fiedler, Marien, and Custers (2020) and Harris, Fiedler, and Custers (2020).

Harris, C., Fiedler, K., Marien, H., Custers, R. (2020). Biased preferences through exploitation: How initial biases are consolidated in reward-rich environments. Journal of Experimental Psychology: General.
Harris, C., Fiedler, K., Custers, R. (2020). When biases beget biases: Exploitation and the maintenance of erroneous action-outcome beliefs. Unpublished manuscript.

analyses.value: Across measures, we expect the two conditions to be biased away from chance level in opposite directions and test this with directional t-tests and the Bayesian equivalent.

dependent.value:
Relative preference: by having participants indicate their estimates on a slider.
Conditional estimates: by having participants indicate their estimates on a slider. 
Choice: by having participants indicate their choice in a repeated choice task over 84 trials.

conditions.value: Two. Participants either first encounter the initial evidence and only then learn which of two fruits earns or loses them points and which fruit they can ignore. Or they first learn the information about the fruit and then encounter the initial evidence.

hypothesis.value:
In this experiment participants will encounter a distribution of initial evidence that is doubly skewed: one of two options occurs more frequently and one of two outcomes occurs more frequently. More specifically, they will encounter either of two locations frequently and will encounter either a lot of grapes and few strawberries, or few strawberries and a lot of grapes. The fruit which occurs infrequent is always the one that earns or loses them points, while the other fruit does not earn them any points. Across trials, participants will therefore often lose points and less frequently earn points. Importantly, in one condition (DN) participants will know from the beginning on which fruit is of relevance and which fruit they can ignore. In the other condition (PC), they only learn this information after encountering the initial evidence. Based on this information, we expect participants to focus on different information and to form different biases.

In the DN condition, we expect participants to form inferences as described by the ratio bias (Denes-Raj, Epstein, and Cole, 1995). That is, we expect them to associate the frequent option with positive outcomes. Even while positive outcomes were seldom in general, participants still encountered more of them with the frequent option than with the infrequent option. By ignoring the baserates, denominator neglect-type inferences are a reasonable prediction.

In the PC condition, we expect participants to form Pseudocontingency-type inferences (Fiedler, Freytag, and Meiser, 2009). That is, we expect them to associate the frequent option with the frequent outcome (losing) and the infrequent option with the infrequent outcome (winning). Through baserate alignment participants would come to opposite conclusions than the DN condition.

Importantly, while we expect participants in both conditions to form (opposing) biases, we expect these biases to be attenuated during sampling and for the later post-sampling DVs in the PC condition but maintained in the DN condition.

Fiedler, K., Freytag, P., Meiser, T. (2009). Pseudocontingencies: an integrative account of an intriguing cognitive illusion. Psychological Review, 116(1), 187-206. doi:10.1037/a0014480
Denes-Raj, V., Epstein, S., Cole, J. (1995). The generality of the ratio-bias phenomenon. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, 21(10), 1083-1092. doi:10.1177/01461672952110009

registration_responses.data: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.
registration_responses.name: Pseudocontingencies vs Denominator Neglect

The sample size was estimated to be around Ni = 100 per cell, or N = 200 total, based on power analyses using G*Power (Faul, Erdfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007). These calculations are based on a 5% alpha-level, 85% statistical power, and effect sizes around d = .3 as reported by Harris, Fiedler, Marien, and Custers (2020) and Harris, Fiedler, and Custers (2020).

Harris, C., Fiedler, K., Marien, H., Custers, R. (2020). Biased preferences through exploitation: How initial biases are consolidated in reward-rich environments. Journal of Experimental Psychology: General.
Harris, C., Fiedler, K., Custers, R. (2020). When biases beget biases: Exploitation and the maintenance of erroneous action-outcome beliefs. Unpublished manuscript.

registration_responses.hypothesis:
In this experiment participants will encounter a distribution of initial evidence that is doubly skewed: one of two options occurs more frequently and one of two outcomes occurs more frequently. More specifically, they will encounter either of two locations frequently and will encounter either a lot of grapes and few strawberries, or few strawberries and a lot of grapes. The fruit which occurs infrequent is always the one that earns or loses them points, while the other fruit does not earn them any points. Across trials, participants will therefore often lose points and less frequently earn points. Importantly, in one condition (DN) participants will know from the beginning on which fruit is of relevance and which fruit they can ignore. In the other condition (PC), they only learn this information after encountering the initial evidence. Based on this information, we expect participants to focus on different information and to form different biases.

In the DN condition, we expect participants to form inferences as described by the ratio bias (Denes-Raj, Epstein, and Cole, 1995). That is, we expect them to associate the frequent option with positive outcomes. Even while positive outcomes were seldom in general, participants still encountered more of them with the frequent option than with the infrequent option. By ignoring the baserates, denominator neglect-type inferences are a reasonable prediction.

In the PC condition, we expect participants to form Pseudocontingency-type inferences (Fiedler, Freytag, and Meiser, 2009). That is, we expect them to associate the frequent option with the frequent outcome (losing) and the infrequent option with the infrequent outcome (winning). Importantly, while we expect participants in both conditions to form (opposing) biases, we expect these biases to be attenuated during sampling and for the later post-sampling DVs in the PC condition but maintained in the DN condition.

Fiedler, K., Freytag, P., Meiser, T. (2009). Pseudocontingencies: an integrative account of an intriguing cognitive illusion. Psychological Review, 116(1), 187-206. doi:10.1037/a0014480
Denes-Raj, V., Epstein, S., Cole, J. (1995). The generality of the ratio-bias phenomenon. Personality and Social Psychology Bulletin, 21(10), 1083-1092. doi:10.1177/01461672952110009

attributes.title: Modelling pig management, health and production

q1.value: Modelling the links between farm management, pig respiratory health and pig production traits.

q2.value: Helen Gray, Mary Friel, Susanna Williamson, Richard P Smith, Conor Goold, Lisa Collins

q3.value:
The aim of this study is to use a multilevel modelling approach to understand the associations between farm management, pig production traits and the reporting of respiratory conditions at slaughter.

Respiratory pathology is commonly recorded in pigs in the abattoir and reflects earlier respiratory disease on farm, which can contribute to a decline in production performance and an increase in mortality. This study will use a pre-existing national-level dataset of health conditions detected at slaughter and compare these to production outcomes and farm management/infrastructure information gathered from UK-based pig producers.

q4.value:
1.	Disinfection: Disinfecting a room/building between batches of pigs will be associated with lower counts of respiratory conditions compared with rooms which are not disinfected between batches.
2.	Batch source: Acquiring pigs from one nursery farm will be associated with lower counts of respiratory conditions, versus sourcing pigs from multiple nursery farms.
3.	Ventilation: Assisted ventilation will be associated with lower counts of respiratory conditions compared with natural ventilation due to greater control over the internal climate and reductions in extreme variations in temperature.
4.	Housing: Housing systems containing straw will be associated with higher counts of respiratory conditions than housing systems not containing straw. 
5.	Time: A higher number of average days spent on farm for finisher pigs will be associated with higher counts of respiratory conditions, compared to fewer days spent on farm. 
6.	A reduction in the counts of respiratory conditions will be associated with more favourable production traits – heavier deadweight, higher average daily gain, lower levels of finisher mortality, and more optimal back fat scores.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This study is a retrospective observational study using longitudinal, repeated measures datasets. The analytical modelling design will account for non-independence of observations from the same group (i.e. farm).

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Author HG has accessed and cleaned the national-level health dataset. Production data were integrated into one dataset by author MF.  The only summary statistic to be calculated is a range of “average days on farm”. This was calculated for model development in order that author HG could simulate data within realistic ranges. For all other variables in the model development stage, national-level production data distributions are being used, along with distributions of data from farms not included in the study.

question.value:
Respiratory conditions data: Data were provided by the Food Standards Agency under the regulations of a non-disclosure agreement.

Production data: Provided by pig producers collaborating with the PigSustain project from their own company records. 

Management data: Provided by pig producers collaborating with the PigSustain project. These data were collected via questionnaires and were filled in either by an employee of the relevant pig production company or by a researcher for PigSustain

q13.value: We have production data from 95 individually-identifiable farms with batches of pigs ranging from 1- 61 batches per farm. We have management data from 105 farms.

q14.value: Sample size was determined by responses to data requests.

q15.value: The decision to stop collecting data was made due to time constraints. Two years after data collection began we stopped trying to recruit more farmers

question.value:
Management (farm-level)
a.	Ventilation: Binary (natural or assisted)
b.	Housing type: Categorical (slatted, straw yards, mix, kennels)
c.	Disinfection: Binary (yes/no)
d.	Batch source: Binary(1/ >1)

It is possible that management variables may be correlated (e.g. farms with straw may always be naturally ventilated). Management variables will be checked for collinearity and complete separation. If variables show high levels of collinearity, one variable will be kept and the other/s removed. The attached table ("collinearity table.docx") shows the justifications for keeping one variable over another, should collinearity occur.

Time on farm (batch-level)
An average number of days that a batch of pigs remained on the farm, from entry to slaughter.

Respiratory Prevalence (batch-level)
Counts of respiratory conditions detected at slaughter, calculated per batch.

Production traits (batch-level)
a.	Average daily gain: Continuous. The average weight (in grams) gained per pig per day, calculated as an average per batch.
b.	Finisher mortality: Counts of finisher pig deaths calculated as a total per batch.
c.	Deadweight: Continuous (Kg). The weight of a pig at slaughter, calculated as an average per batch.
d.	Backfat (P2 score): Continuous. A probe depth (normally between 8-18mm) calculated as an average per batch.

Data have been cleaned to remove outliers from slaughter data (see below) and to remove records of farms with no unique identifiers from production and management data (as these cannot be matched to slaughter health data). Health, management and production datasets have been matched and integrated. None of the variables of interest have been analysed.

We will test three Bayesian multilevel models with random intercepts, with the production traits as the outcome variables and the management and respiratory variables predictor variables. A Leave One Out (LOO) cross-validation model comparison will then be used to select the most appropriate model. The production outcomes will be run through the models separately, allowing for the eventuality that different models may be better suited to different production traits.

q20.value:
Respiratory: Respiratory counts will be centered around the mean. Counts of respiratory data for each batch will be divided by the batch size to give a prevalence.

Average daily gain: This is a normally distributed variable used as a predictor for P2. It will be centered around the mean.

Ventilation, disinfection and batch source: These are all binary variables which will be centered around the mean.

Housing: This is a categorical variable which will be recoded using sum-to-zero contrasts. This means all other parameters are evaluated at the mean outcome variable of all of the housing categories.

Batch size: Batch size will be centered around the mean.

Time: The average number of days which a batch of pigs remained on the farm will be centered around the mean.

q21.value: Comparisons between estimates from the posterior distributions will be made by comparing Bayesian credible intervals. For continuous predictors, comparisons will be made to zero.

q22.value: Outliers have already been identified for the slaughter health data, and were found to contain errors relating to total numbers of pigs slaughtered. The data contained cases of greater numbers of pigs slaughtered than those reported in annual UK statistics, with prominent inflations seen in 2014. Outliers were identified by calculating the number of pigs slaughtered per abattoir, per day. If an abattoir was reported to have slaughtered > 10,000 pigs/day, the records corresponding to that abattoir for that day were removed from the dataset. 10,000 pigs/abattoir/day was chosen as we are not aware of any UK abattoir able to process that number of pigs in one day, indicating that reports of such numbers are incorrect. Note here, that only total numbers of pigs have been looked at in these data and the variable of interest (respiratory prevalence) had not yet been calculated when these data discrepancies were found.

q23.value:
Missing data mainly come from the fact that production data cannot be matched to the years of slaughter data with which we were provided. Some producers gave data from pre-August 2009 (44 farms, 336 batches)  and post-2015 (71 farms, 462 batches)  and the slaughter records we have begin August 2009 and finish December 2015. We treated these data as missing completely at random and data will not be imputed.

Some missing data (173 lorry loads of pigs taken to the abattoir) come from outliers removed in the slaughter data (see 21). It is unknown why these data were anomalous (after speaking to the data provider) and for this reason, we treated the data as missing completely at random and data will not be imputed.

The last cases of missing data come from unsuccessful matching between production data and slaughter data. This could be for a range of reasons including: 
•	Typos or errors in input from producers (production data) or processors (slaughter data) meaning unique farm identifiers could not be matched between datasets
•	Changes in farm identifier (herdmark / slapmark - a tattoo given to pigs before slaughter to identify their farm of origin)
•	Incomplete matches between production data and slaughter data. This occurs where the number of pigs sold in a batch does not match the number slaughtered within a certain timeframe. Mismatches can be either too few pigs matched (more sold than are returned from the slaughter data) or too many matched (fewer sold than are returned from the slaughter data). This may be because of the matching criteria imposed.

Out of the 65 farms which were suitable for matching, three farms did not match any batches. Out of the remaining 62 farms, four farms had no incomplete matching and the remaining 58 farms had at least 1 batch of incomplete matching. As the reasons for mismatches are not related farm to production, management and respiratory values or farm identifiers, we treated the data as missing completely at random and data will not be imputed.

attributes.title: Teaching Middle School Students with ESN to Solve Multiplicative Comparison Word Problems
attributes.description: We will use a single-case multiple probe across dyads to evaluate the effectiveness and feasibility of teacher-implemented modified schema-based instruction (MSBI) to teach middle school students with ESN to solve multiplicative comparison word problems.

q1.value: Teaching Middle School Students with ESN to Solve Multiplicative Comparison Word Problems

q2.value: Jenny Root, Sarah Cox, Addie McConomy

q3.value:
The purpose of the study is to evaluate the effectiveness and feasibility of teacher-implemented modified schema-based instruction (MSBI) on word problem solving for students with ESN. Specifically, multiplicative comparison word problems are targeted. We will also assess whether students can generalize skills to video-based problems (rather than word problems). Research questions: 
1.1 Is there a functional relation between teacher-implemented MSBI and an increased level of independence in solving multiplicative comparison word problems? 
1.2 What is the effect of teacher-implemented MSBI on generalization of problem solving skills? 
1.3What are teacher and student perceptions of the intervention? 
1.4 What are the essential features of the intervention to include in fidelity measures?

q4.value:
There is a functional relation between teacher-implemented MSBI and solving word problems.
There is a functional relation between teacher-implemented MSBI and solving video-based problems.
Teacher-implemented MSBI is feasible for teaching multiplicative comparison problems.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q9.value: We will incorporate randomization of the order of problems students solve by allowing each dyad to select the theme daily and which problems are assigned to model/lead/test phases.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants: three special education teachers and their middle school students with ESN who pass pre-screening and have parent permission & give assent. No compensation for any participants.

q13.value: Three special education teachers will be included and 6-8 students.

q14.value: We will have four tiers, exceeding the minimum need for three demonstrations of effect and 3 different points in time.

q15.value: We will cease data collection if: (a) participants withdraw consent/assent, (b) participants do not make adequate progress after 10 instructional sessions, and/or (c) students are no longer in school

question.value: We manipulate introduction of instruction / intervention (MSBI). This will include providing guided practice prior to independent practice and review of errors at the conclusion of independent practice.

1)	(Primary) Independence in solving MC word problems, measured by steps of TA completed independently correct (out of 6)
2)	Problems solved, measured by # of problems with correct numerical answer 
3)	Generalization of problem solving, measured by same rubric as primary DV & problems solved

Visual analysis of single-case research
Tau-U for effect size

q22.value: No data points will be excluded

registration_responses.q1: Teaching Middle School Students with ESN to Solve Multiplicative Comparison Word Problems
registration_responses.q2: Jenny Root, Sarah Cox, Addie McConomy
registration_responses.q3:
The purpose of the study is to evaluate the effectiveness and feasibility of teacher-implemented modified schema-based instruction (MSBI) on word problem solving for students with ESN. Specifically, multiplicative comparison word problems are targeted. We will also assess whether students can generalize skills to video-based problems (rather than word problems). Research questions: 
1.1 Is there a functional relation between teacher-implemented MSBI and an increased level of independence in solving multiplicative comparison word problems? 
1.2 What is the effect of teacher-implemented MSBI on generalization of problem solving skills? 
1.3What are teacher and student perceptions of the intervention? 
1.4 What are the essential features of the intervention to include in fidelity measures?
registration_responses.q4:
There is a functional relation between teacher-implemented MSBI and solving word problems.
There is a functional relation between teacher-implemented MSBI and solving video-based problems.
Teacher-implemented MSBI is feasible for teaching multiplicative comparison problems.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q9: We will incorporate randomization of the order of problems students solve by allowing each dyad to select the theme daily and which problems are assigned to model/lead/test phases.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to creation of data
registration_responses.q13: Three special education teachers will be included and 6-8 students.
registration_responses.q14: We will have four tiers, exceeding the minimum need for three demonstrations of effect and 3 different points in time.
registration_responses.q15: We will cease data collection if: (a) participants withdraw consent/assent, (b) participants do not make adequate progress after 10 instructional sessions, and/or (c) students are no longer in school
registration_responses.q22: No data points will be excluded
registration_responses.q8.question: Single-case multiple probe across participants
registration_responses.q12.question: Participants: three special education teachers and their middle school students with ESN who pass pre-screening and have parent permission & give assent. No compensation for any participants.
registration_responses.q16.question: We manipulate introduction of instruction / intervention (MSBI). This will include providing guided practice prior to independent practice and review of errors at the conclusion of independent practice.
registration_responses.q17.question:
1)	(Primary) Independence in solving MC word problems, measured by steps of TA completed independently correct (out of 6)
2)	Problems solved, measured by # of problems with correct numerical answer 
3)	Generalization of problem solving, measured by same rubric as primary DV & problems solved
registration_responses.q19.question:
Visual analysis of single-case research
Tau-U for effect size

attributes.title: Construction interdépendante du soi, marqueur de régulation émotionnelle ( TSOC 2A)
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

question2a.value:
Variable indépendante 1 : Construction de soi à 2 modalités
-	Indépendance
-	Interdépendance
Variable indépendante 2 : Valence émotionnelle à 2 modalités
-	Induction émotion négative
-	Induction émotion positive

question2b.value: Variable dépendante : suppression des émotions négatives

question10b.value:
- Induction interdépendance du soi social eye/visage neutre pendant une tâche de flanker.
- Séparé les personnes selon les résultats au questionnaire avec la mesure de la construction de soi de Singelis
- 2 conditions voient ensuite une série d’image IAPS négatives et une condition contrôle où ils voient des images neutres avec soit logo neutre, soit logo yeux.
- On mesure grâce au formulaire de ressenti auto-rapporté le taux de régulation émotionnelle (suppression des émotions négatives.)

question4b.value: Les participants sont sélectionnés aléatoirement, dans la rue, dans les universités et dans l’entourage de l’expérimentateur.

question5b.value: Les données sont recueillies soit dans des box de l’université Paris Descartes, soit au domicile de l’expérimentateur.

question6b.value: Par soucis d’économie expérimentale, l’échantillon est composé de 35 étudiants.

question8b.value: 1.	Les réponses ne seront pas prises en compte si elles sont trop extrêmes par rapport à la courbe de Gaüss. Si elles sont incomplètes. Et si l’induction de la construction de soi interdépendante est défaillante, celle-ci étant vérifiable avec le test de construction de soi.

question1a.value:
1/ Les personnes présentant une construction interdépendante du soi vont avoir plus tendance à supprimer leurs émotions que celles avec une construction de soi indépendante dans le cadre d’une ambivalence émotionnelle.

2/ Dans le cadre d’un échange émotionnelle avec une personne proche, les personnes présentant une construction du soi interdépendante du soi vont avoir plus tendance à supprimer leurs émotions positives que négatives.

question2a.value: Il existerait une interaction entre l’interdépendance du soi et la présence d’autrui même quand elle n’est que symbolique. On s’attend donc à une interaction ordonnée entre l’effet de la construction de soi et l’effet des émotions.

registration_responses.datacompletion: No, data collection has not begun

1/ Les personnes présentant une construction interdépendante du soi vont avoir plus tendance à supprimer leurs émotions que celles avec une construction de soi indépendante dans le cadre d’une ambivalence émotionnelle.

2/ Dans le cadre d’un échange émotionnelle avec une personne proche, les personnes présentant une construction du soi interdépendante du soi vont avoir plus tendance à supprimer leurs émotions positives que négatives.
registration_responses.description-hypothesis.question2a: Il existerait une interaction entre l’interdépendance du soi et la présence d’autrui même quand elle n’est que symbolique. On s’attend donc à une interaction ordonnée entre l’effet de la construction de soi et l’effet des émotions.

- Induction interdépendance du soi social eye/visage neutre pendant une tâche de flanker.
- Séparé les personnes selon les résultats au questionnaire avec la mesure de la construction de soi de Singelis
- 2 conditions voient ensuite une série d’image IAPS négatives et une condition contrôle où ils voient des images neutres avec soit logo neutre, soit logo yeux.

Les données sont recueillies soit dans des box de l’université Paris Descartes, soit au domicile de l’expérimentateur.
Par soucis d’économie expérimentale, l’échantillon est composé de 35 étudiants.

attributes.title: Mental health interventions for schools in Nepal
Transparency and open science standards in the policies of medical and health science journals
attributes.description: An evaluation of the policies of health and medical science journals with respect to transparency and open science standards

q1.value: Engagement with transparent and open science standards in the policies of selected medical and health science journals: an audit and evaluation

q2.value: Hopin Lee, Georgia C. Richards, David Nunan, Antoni Dariusz Gardener, Yi Jie Gifford Tan, Ellie Hick, Chloe Jacklin

q4.value:
Hypotheses 
We hypothesise that the policies of high-ranking medical and health science journals will adhere to all aspects of the TOP guideline and require disclosure in accordance with ICMJE standards;

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: audit and evaluation - Audit of transparency standards for 20 high-ranking (by Google Scholar h-index) medical and health science journals using the TOP guideline. A ‘Letter to the editor’ (LTE; or similar article type as per journal) will be submitted to all journals relaying the findings of the TOP guideline. In a follow-up study to this study, we will assess the potential impact of simply informing journals of our TOP audit findings compared with the addition of informing them about a future re-audit of their journal.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will extract journal policies on February 10, 2020. We will save the policies that are available in downloadable file formats and we will create screenshot image files of the policies available online only. Each policy will have a time and date stamp when collected. For each journal, we will review the level of adherence to the minimum transparency research standards as suggested by the TOP Committee [Nosek et al 2015] using the COS scorecard (standards 1-8). We will also extract the level of adherence to standards in declaring conflict of interest (standards 1-4). Two authors will independently extract data from each journal’s instructions for authors using a prespecified data extraction sheet. Disagreements in extraction will be resolved via discussion, or where necessary, through consulting a third author. 

The COS scorecard was developed to assess the transparency and openness policies of social-personality psychology journals. The COS scorecard includes the 8 transparency standards found in the TOP Guidelines (https://cos.io/top/) as well as three additional items (TOP signatory, registered reports, open science badges). The grand total is calculated by combining the TOP total (the combined score of each of the 8 transparency standards (scored between 0 to 24) where each standard is scored from 0 to 3 in relation to the level of guideline adherence), with the scores for additional three items, top signatory (0 = no, 1 = yes), registered reports (0 = no, 2 = yes) and open science badges (0 = no, 2 = yes). The grand total score is out of a possible 29.

Conflict of interests relates to situations that may arise when the professional judgment concerning a primary interest (such as patients' welfare or the validity of research) may be influenced by a secondary interest (such as financial gain). The International Committee of Medical Journal Editors (ICMJE) has established standards for disclosing actual or potential conflicts of interest. It is recommended that all journals request authors to declare any actual or potential conflicts of interest when submitting a manuscript for publication. We will appraise the conflict of interest requirements for each journal, in particular, their adherence to 4 of the standards found in the ICMJE disclosure form (appendix 1). Adherence will be measured on a 0 to 4 scale to reflect each standard.

We will synthesize the scores of all journals and create a league table, ranking journals by highest to lowest TOP score. The audit findings will be written up and submitted to Nature Medicine. 

In a follow-up study to this study, we will assess the potential impact of simply informing journals of our TOP audit findings compared with the addition of informing them about a future re-audit of their journal. A separate protocol will be designed and registered for this proof-of-concept study.

q14.value: We will assess high-ranked journals in the ‘Health & Medical Sciences’ subcategory of Google Scholar as listed on Friday, 31 January 2020 (full list available online here: https://scholar.google.com/citations?view_op=top_venues&hl=en&vq=med)

question.value: The primary outcome is the TOP score (out of 29) for each journal. The secondary outcome is journals requirements for disclosing conflicts of interest (score out of 4 from the ICMJE).
We will calculate the total TOP score and ICMJE score for each journal.

q25.value:
Disclosure of interests: GCR is funded by the NIHR SPCR, the Naji Foundation and the Rotary Foundation to study for a Doctor of Philosophy at the University of Oxford. GCR is an Ambassador for the Centre for Open Science and is the Editorial Registrar for BMJ Evidence Based Medicine. HL is funded by the National Health and Medical Research Council (grant
no. APP1126767); National Institute for Health Research (NIHR) Collaboration for Leadership in Applied Health Research and Care Oxford at Oxford Health NHS Foundation Trust; received
project funding from the Berkeley Initiative for Transparency in the Social Sciences, a program of the Center for Effective Global Action (CEGA), with support from the Laura and John Arnold
Foundation; and is a Catalyst for the Berkeley Initiative for Transparency in the Social Sciences. DN is a member of the Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) steering committee to support the new Physical Activity and Lifestyle clinical priority. He has received funding for research from the NHS National Institute for Health Research School for Primary Care Research (NIHR SPCR) and the RCGP for independent research projects related to physical activity and dietary interventions. The views expressed are those of the author and not necessarily those of the NHS, the NIHR, the RCGP or the Department of Health.


APPENDIX
Appendix 1: ICMJE Form for Disclosure of Potential Conflicts of Interest
The following 4 sections from the ICMJE form for disclosure of potential conflicts of interest will be used as a “gold standard” to measure journal adherence:
1) The work under consideration for publication.
Did you or your institution at any time receive payment or services from a third party (government, commercial, private foundation, etc.) for any aspect of the submitted work (including but not limited to grants, data monitoring board, study design, manuscript preparation, statistical analysis, etc.)?
2) Relevant financial activities outside the submitted work.
Indicate whether you have financial relationships (regardless of amount of compensation) with entities as described in the instructions.
3) Intellectual Property.
Do you have any patents, whether planned, pending or issued, broadly relevant to the work?
4) Relationships not covered above
Are there other relationships or activities that readers could perceive to have influenced, or that give the appearance of potentially influencing, what you wrote in the submitted work?

attributes.title: Multigroup CFA effect sizes for more than 2 groups

summary.value:
This project aims at developing effect sizes for usage in multigroup CFA (and more generally speaking SEM) for more than 2 groups.

Nyes & Drasgow (2011) first provided the dMACS effect size which is analogous to Cohen's d.

Here I aim to derive an R² equivalent for SEM, explore its properties in simulations studies, and make it available through an R package.

registration_responses.summary:
This project aims at developing effect sizes for usage in multigroup CFA (and more generally speaking SEM) for more than 2 groups.

Nyes & Drasgow (2011) first provided the dMACS effect size which is analogous to Cohen's d.

Here I aim to derive an R² equivalent for SEM, explore its properties in simulations studies, and make it available through an R package.
